addressleaf.section:
Copie of my l
re
to S
r
Robert Cecill N
o
26 95

page.lettertext:
fol.32r
May it please yo
r
H. to advertise her
Ma
tie
,
that
e
18 of this moneth, I receaved her gratious l
re
of
e 4 w
t
an other to
e
States,
which according
to my charge, I presented unto them, in their
publicke meeting, and accomplished as muche,
as I was otherwise enjoyned, by a verbal decla-
ration. But
M
r
Caron
sent them worde, above
ten dayes before,
at having had as he related
co
m
unication w
t
my
LL.
in case they would
be readie w
t
some succo
r
of shipping against
e Spanish preparation, her Ma
tie
would be plea-
sed, to lette falle for a season her poursuite of
remboursement. Wherat they joyed then excee-
dinglie, and reputed it expedient, to imparte
e
tidinges out of hand to
e Provinces abroade.
which was done w
t
expedition, to meete w
t
many
dangers, which it seemed they feared might
growe upon
e soddaine, unles
e people, by some mea-
nes were put in better hart. But nowe I am
instructed by
e l
re
of yo
r
H. that in this there
was an error of too muche hast in M
r
Caron,
before he had receaved her Hig
es
resolution.
Having had among themselves some tyme of
consultation, upon
e l
re
and my demandes, they
delivered me an answear, full of thankes and
duetifull acknowledgement of
e grace
at they re-
ceaved, which could never have come, as they de-
clared, in a meeter season for their welfare.
And touching
at which was required, of
e aide they
were to yeld of 30 shippes of a certain bourden,
they made no further question, but
at when it had
bin mooved to
e States in particular, they would
i
m
ediately take order,
at her Ma
tie
should be ser-
ved, to her best contentation. But for
e
point of defraieng
e auxiliarie forces, they tooke it
fol.32v
altogether in
e self same nature, w
t
her former demand
which could by no meanes be effected, but by
e Gene-
rallitie, to whome they founde it all
e danger,
To notefie
at her Ma
tie
will ende her Treatie w
t
e
Contrey. I have urged upon it w
t
dyvers
replies,
at
e people might be wonne by their good
endevors, that it was not a thing to be stoode on,
that
e su
m
e would be but smalle, yet esteemed to
be great in regard of their willingnesse, and
e
speeches
at would goe of this negotiation, w
t
divers
other reasons:
for
to
whiche they gave no other answear
then they have done heeretofore, but
at they meant
to resume
e mater againe, and to examine it
throughlie, and doe all
at they could to satisfie her
Ma
tie
. But as for me I am persuaded, that
they will never yelde to any thinge, to howe litle so-
ever
e su
m
e be abbridged, if it come to be deman-
ded as a debt already dewe, by expiration of
e Trea-
tie. For
at is
e place, where they thinke they are
wrunge, and
e people, they imagine will by no meanes
endure it. For w
ch
I rest out of hope of any better
satisfaction, and to say w
at
I thinke, under humble
correction, I hold it whollie requisit, to attend yet
a while a fitter opportunitie, w
ch
e State of thinges
heere and tyme must present, and heereafter to
project some suche forme of proceeding as may come
neerer to their liking, and yet conclude
e same
effect, w
t
at which is required. They have
secretly discoursed, about
e sending of some persons,
to give her Ma
tie
more content, then hath bin
done by their answear delivered to me: and if
it chance to be resolved, it is lyke to be declared
in their l
re
to her Ma
tie
, wherof in lyke sorte, to
interpose my opinion, w
t
out note of presumption,
fol.33r
I should thinke
at suche a message, would make
very muche for
e service of her Hig
es
for
at in
this case, when they can not be persuaded, to
assent to her demande, both
e sending of their
Deputies will seeme more respective, in
e
judgement of
e world, then their bare kinde
of writing, and it may be at their coming,
they will make some fruitefull motion, or be
wonne by good remonstrance, to reco
m
end heere
at home some special purpose of her Ma
tie
,
or if neither of both should happen, yet me
thinkes in these sturres, and turbulent times,
where
e cause is so co
m
on between
e two Contreys
her Hig
es
can not be but holpen, by
e conference
and Counsaile, and presence of suche persons, as
I presume they will depute. And
where her Ma
tie
maketh mention of
M
r
Barne-
velts
ouverture, wherein there was good hope, both
of this and greater maters, I have mooved him
about it, and debated it at lenght, but he
putteth me in minde,
at
e time is farre other,
and their State more afflicted, and
at they have
bin at
e charge sins
at he and I talked of
20000
li
disboursed to
e
F
r
Kinges
use, and at
great expenses in
e field, where they had not
then their armie, at
e tyme of
at ouverture,
nor yet in 3 moneths after: and
had
perhaps, as
he supposeth, if this plotte had bin accepted,
remayned still in garrison. Withall he doth
maintaine (as I have formerly declared to
be
e opinion both of him, and of divers heere
besides) that there is no possibilitie to induce
e
Common sort, to condescend to restitution, by
vertue of
e Contract, for
at they will not un-
derstand it, but as a mater of right, and a just
fol.33v
stipulation, and
at it ought to be continued: for
which of force they must be wonne, by presenting
unto them some other newe Treatie, with some suche
Covenants, and conditions, as neede not charge her
Ma
tie
and yet tie
e Contrey, to those paiments w
ch
her Ma
tie
will require in regard of her debourse-
ments. And heere I cannot by
e way
but advertise yo
r
H.
at sins my last coming hi-
ther, I have found M Barnevelt farre out of tem-
per, partly through
e speeches of some of his
collegues, which dislyke of his dealing, as if his ouver-
ture to me, had bin a motive to her Ma
tie
, when she saw
at of themselves, they would yeld to some good portion,
to cast upon
em
e bourden of a greater demande: wher-
with they crushe him, as he sayeth, very often in their
meetinges, partly also he is grieved w
t
some w
at
written
out of
England,
of
e opinion of some,
at all his dea-
ling heere w
t
me, was but dalliance and cunning to
winne tyme of her Ma
tie
which is also a touche to me
in particular in respect of credulitie, or some other
kinde of weaknesse, in
at I could not see
e practise.
But for my self, I could wishe
at
e mater then
proposed, had com aswell in some forme, w
ch
her Ma
tie
could have lyked, as it was cleere, and out of question,
that there was no dissimulation. For as for any
abuse
at M
r
Barnevelt could offer, by
e meanes
of
e Ouverture, it was so hard for him to doe it,
and so many must concurre, and it had steeded
him so litle, as if
e circumstance of thinges in
e
nature of
at cause, and in
e forme of this gouver-
nement, and in
e maner of his conferring, and
proceeding heere w
t
me, be duely weighed w
t
all his
pointes, I doe not thinke to finde any,
at will
stand in
at opinion. It is advertised
hither from very good place,
at
e Administrator
fol.34r
of
Saxonie,
the
Elector of Mayence
,
e
Archebishop
of Saltsburgh
, and
e rest are elected to worke
e feate of Pacification, have concluded among
themselves, to goe in hand w
t
at attempt, about
Fe
b
next: w
ch
yet we thinke will be differred,
till
e coming of the
Archeduke,
who many men
thinke will be longer in coming: because they
say, he hath in Province many yrons in
e fyre,
and is in hand w
t
Casot
e Consul of
Marseilles,
to deliver
at towne to
e
K. of Spaine
.
But for
e mater of Pacification, this people is
inabled, by an excellent late token of gods goodness
eunto them, to choake
e Enemie very soundly, and
to dashe
at practise altogether. For there hath
bin very happelie intercepted of late in
e Medi-
terrane Sea, a special packet of l
res
, which were
written by
e Marquis of Haurey, and
John Baptista
Taxis
, to
e K. of Spaine, and sent hither to
e States
by
Mons
r
D'Esdignieres
. By
at of Taxis is
discovered a double falsehood in their meaning,
both towardes
e
Emperor
and
e States: and also
otherwise his l
re
is full of fraudulent courses.
They were written both in Cypher, and decyphred
in suche sorte, as I have sent yow
e transcript,
by
Mons
r
de S
t
Aldegonde
: and were by
e States
delivered to me, w
t
an earnest request that they
might not be divulged but to her Ma
tie
and
my LL., to
e ende in tyme convenient, they may
serve to be produced, to
e best advantage of
their purpose. Heere is secret notice
geven, and it is thought over true,
at
e
Co.
of Hohenlo
, who is nowe in
Germanie,
doth im-
ploy all his meanes to
e advancement of a
Peace, and is wholly busied among
e Princes
fol.34v
in maters prejudiciall, to
e State of this Union:
all proceeding of dislyke between him, and
Co. Maurice
,
Moreover it is reported,
at he will meete
e
P. of Orenge
in his way to these Contreys, and w
at
his dealing may be further, it is feared of dyvers.
It is undoubtedly heere beleeved,
at
there will be a truce betweene
Spaine
and
France:
at
e least of a yere. We have also heere
intelligence,
at
e Gouverno
r
of
Boullen
by
Calais,
hath suche dooinges of late w
t
e
D. D'Esper-
non
, as many men see cause to doubt of his loy-
altie. As they doe in lyke maner of
e holding
out of Calais, which is not well provided, as
e Co
m
on voice goeth: and sith we heare
at de
Fuentes maketh great preparation, it is suspected
of many,
at his dessigne is to besiege it.
The
F
r
King
hath written to
e States, to
knowe w
at
kinde of warre they will make
e next
yere, whether offensive or deffensive, to
e end
he may thereafter direct his owne affaires,
And their answear thereunto, he desireth to
receave by his Ambassado
r
Mons
r
Buzanval
:
to whome he hath written to returne with
e
same, and to give him information of their
Estate in many maters. But I can not yet
perceave, that the States can well determine,
w
at
answear to make as touching their warre.
Some of those in these quarters
at
have best intelligence out of Spaine, give it
out for certaine,
at
e bruited preparations
are nothing so great, as heere they did imagine.
To come to
at last which toucheth
my self, I am to sue unto yo
r
H. very humblie
and earnestly,
at her Ma
tie
may be moved,
fol.35r
to grant me licence to returne: wherein before
I went from home my
L. T
re
r
promised to favo
r
my petition, and I hope my
L. of Essex
will put
his helping hand to it. For I protest unto yo
r
H., if I might but have
e leasure to sette some
order in my State, w
ch
is charged with expences
more then most men doe imagine, and is ma-
ny wayes wracked to my very great detriment,
by reason of my jorneys, it would to me be
all a mater, to live at home or abroade,
either heere or wheresoever, as her Ma
tie
may
be pleased to thinke me fitte
to
serve her turne.
And so I take &c.
From
e Hage 26 N
o
95
.
